author: muddlebee
content:
Thanks team for the wonderful session ðŸš€ and <@!642887713246150666> for hosting it <a:lighthouse2:771415681995636737> 

Today we explored around EIP-4396 https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/186f930697148e0eb2b526d9f16b06bf2e4ae605/EIPS/eip-4396.md
and all the implications on throughput and security.

also some discussions around cryptoeconomics, which led me to explore more on it : https://vitalik.ca/general/2021/09/26/limits.html. Sharing some part of the article below

> If cryptoeconomics needs a political layer, and is no longer self-sufficient, what good is cryptoeconomics? One answer might be that cryptoeconomics can be the basis for securing more democratic and values-centered governance, where incentives can reduce reliance on military or police power. Through mature designs that integrate with less-economic purposes, cryptoeconomics might transcend its initial limitations. Politics needs cryptoeconomics, too ... by integrating cryptoeconomics with democracy, both legacies seem poised to benefit.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
IMO targeting EOY for an _existing_ testnet is way too aggressive.  Don't forget infra providers need to be able to provide access to the existing testnets for our customers, so we need stable officially supported clients that support the merge, and time enough to retool our infrastructure to handle the added complexity of running both clients simultaneously.  

I think such a schedule totally makes sense for devtests and _maybe_ even Sepolia (though again IIF stable merge-ready clients are released a couple weeks before the merge happens on Sepolia).

Rather than picking a date, I'd rather we focus on what are the requirements for performing the merge on an existing testnet, then work forward from there rather than backwards from a target date.

author: timbeiko
content: The reason for the date conversation is that if we _don't_ think we can transition Ropsten early 2021, then the difficulty bomb will go off on it

author: timbeiko
content:
At a high level, what I think we need for the transition is:
1. Final specs for the merge
2. Those specs implemented + tested (to an extent, but less than mainnet) in clients 
3. Heads up to infra teams

For (3), I'm curious what the best way is to get folks like Infura, Etherscan, etc. running on post-merge infra? Would love to discuss on the community call this Friday if you can make it.

author: timbeiko

author: gcolvin
content: Does the bridge maintain formatting, edits and deletions?  If not we need to be careful to use plain text and not edit prior posts to be sure that messages on one side of the bridge mean the same thing on the other side, and to control whether URLs do or do not cause an unknowable graphic to appear.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
> what the best way is to get folks like Infura, Etherscan, etc. running on post-merge infra?

One suggestion is to release official clients w/ support for Pithos (so we can test on official builds on a new devnet) or wait until Sepolia is cut-over to the Merge before scheduling the current testnets.
